instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message:
This one has touchpad corroded, which yet has to be replaced. As for the keyboard, it only reacts to power on off button. <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H_TPAD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_TPAD</SIGNAL> are present. Tried another keyboard, didn't work. 

Can this model work without touchpad connected? I'd like to get the keyboard working for now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message: it needs the touchpad connected for the keyboard to work other than the power

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message: Keyboard WILL NOT work without the trackpad. Need to try new trackpad and trackpad flex

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message:
I tried another trackpad and now both trackpad and keyboard are working. 

In settings, there is no trackpad found. Should I worry about it?

To change trackpad, I need to remove the battery. Can it be removed with a hot gun or should I opt for a better option?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message: We do not use hot air, just slowly work something flat under the glue a little at a time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message:
[QUOTE="djdblaster, post: 43962"]I tried another trackpad and now both trackpad and keyboard are working.

In settings, there is no trackpad found. Should I worry about it?

To change trackpad, I need to remove the battery. Can it be removed with a hot gun or should I opt for a better option?[/QUOTE]

Don't use a heat gun near the battery unless you want it to blow up in your face, same goes with metal pry tools... stay away from anything metal or sharp.

I douse the area with 99% iso and then use the ifixit cards to slip under each cell and cut through the glue. I can get one out in 5 mins or so.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message:
Battery removed without heat and iso. Thanks all for tips! Mark as solved. 

P.S. I've replied earlier to this thread as "Mark solved", but apparently those attack on forums(?) took out some latest comments out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message: were the removed posts in regards to using iso?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Touchpad (water damaged) + Keyboard not working
threads.message: Should be as same as the last post.
